Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 11:34AM PatSG wrote: Elaine, your posts continue to show how splendidly you do cope, and how you inspire others to do likewise.  In the case of pain meds, more is less.  As in more meds, less pain.  As I understand it with regards to pain management, standard wisdom of the day indicates that when pain meds are taken more routinely, the pain is controlled better and the person typically ends up using less medication overall once pain control has been achieved.  I think ongoing pain just saps one's energies, both body and mind, and energy seems so important in our ability to deal with this disease.  So please treat yourself kindly today and Reach for Relief in the form of your codeine bottle!  Let us know how you do, Pat
Posts.Title: Shout at me, girls ElaineD leprechaun

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 12:28PM PatSG wrote: Thanks, LuAnn for your post, and to all of you for your posts containing so much honesty, hope and courage.  And humor.  When first dx with mets, of course I had to press my onc to answer the "how long" question.  Was given an "18-month average stats" kind of answer.  Am past that now and doing well.  Of course there is often anxiety about the unknown.  And sadness when yet another death from this disease is posted.  Yet it is also so heartening to see all the many stories here, to share in others' experiences and know that I am not alone.  And that a person can live well and long (dare I add, "and prosper"?) with this disease.  I have been fortunate enough to see my daughter graduate from college, and hope to see my son do the same in another couple of years.  And so, life goes on.
